paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Lab:** Working with Apache Kafka Streaming Messages
**Objective:** Read streaming data from a Kafka topic and send data to a Kafka topic.
**File locations:**
    Test data (local): /home/devuser/data/telco/activations_stream/
    Test script: /home/devuser/bin/devsh/scripts/streamtest-kafka.sh
    Solution files: /home/devuser/bin/devsh/scripts/streaming-kafka-source.scalaspark
                    /home/devuser/bin/devsh/scripts/streaming-kafka-sink.scalaspark
**Successful outcome:** 
**Before you begin:** 
**Related lessons:** 

---

msg.data:
About

Lab: Working with Apache Kafka Streaming Messages
Objective: Read streaming data from a Kafka topic and send data to a Kafka topic.
File locations:

Test data (local): $DEVDATA/activations_stream/
Test script: $DEVSH/scripts/streamtest-kafka.sh
Solution files: streaming-kafka-source.pyspark
                streaming-kafka-source.scalaspark
                streaming-kafka-sink.pyspark
                streaming-kafka-sink.scalaspark

Successful outcome:
Before you begin:
Related lessons:

Setup

None
Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Read Messages from a Kafka Source

In this section, you will create a streaming Kafka DataFrame based on device activation Kafka messages in the `activations` topic. The message content is in JSON format. You will extract the required data and calculate the number of activations by model name.

The Kafka messages will be generated by a test script using the files in `/home/devuser/data/telco/activations_stream/`. You may wish to review the data before proceeding.

msg.data:
Read Messages from a Kafka Source

In this section, you will create a streaming Kafka DataFrame based on device activation
Kafka messages in the activations topic. The message content is in JSON format.
You will extract the required data and calculate the number of activations by model
name.

The Kafka messages will be generated by a test script using the files in
$DEVDATA/activations_stream/. You may wish to review the data before proceeding.

paragraphs.title: 1 - Terminate any Spark shells
paragraphs.text:
%md
If you currently have a Spark shell running in a terminal session, exit it.

paragraphs.title: 2 - Create a topic
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create the `activations` topic for the streaming messages.

msg.data:
$ kafka-topics --create --zookeeper localhost:2181 \
    --partitions 2 --replication-factor 1 --topic activations

paragraphs.title: 3 - Start a new local Spark shell
paragraphs.text:
%md
Start a new Scala Spark shell.

    $ spark-shell --master local[2]

msg.data:
The course exercise environment's resources are not sufficient to run a streaming
application. Start a new Python or Scala Spark shell running locally instead of on the
cluster.

$ pyspark --master local[2]

$ spark-shell --master local[2]

paragraphs.title: 4 - Create a streaming DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a streaming DataFrame called `kafkaDF` using the following settings:

- Format: `kafka`
- `kafka.bootstrap.servers` option: `localhost:9092`
- `subscribe` option: `activations` (topic name)

msg.data:
Create a streaming DataFrame called kafkaDF using the following settings:

  • Format: kafka
  • kafka.bootstrap.servers option: localhost:9092
  • subscribe option: activations (topic name)

paragraphs.title: 5 - Display the schema of the DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
Note that the `value` column contains binary values.

msg.data: Note that the value column contains binary values.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Create a new DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a new DataFrame called `stringValueDF` containing only the value column from `kafkaDF`. The new `value` should be string type.

Hint: use the `cast("string")` function on the value column reference.

msg.data:
Create a new DataFrame called stringValueDF containing only the value
column from kafkaDF. The new value should be string type.

Hint: use the cast("string") function on the value column reference.

paragraphs.title: 7 - Confirm the column type was changed
paragraphs.text:
%md
Display the schema to confirm that the column type was changed correctly.

paragraphs.title: 8 - Create a new DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a new DataFrame called `activationsDF` with a single column called `activation`. The column should contain sub-columns for the four values in the activation JSON records: `acct_num`, `dev_id`, `phone`, and `model`.

**a.** Create a schema to map the JSON values to columns.

msg.data:
Create a new DataFrame called activationsDF with a single column called
activation. The column should contain sub-columns for the four values in the
activation JSON records: acct_num, dev_id, phone, and model.

a. Create a schema to map the JSON values to columns.

paragraphs.text:
%spark2
import org.apache.spark.sql.types._

val activationsSchema = StructType( List(
StructField("acct_num", IntegerType),
StructField("dev_id", StringType),
StructField("phone", StringType),
StructField("model", StringType)))

paragraphs.title: 8 b - Parse the value column
paragraphs.text:
%md
Use the `from_json` function to parse the values in the `value` column to the schema above.

msg.data: b. Use the from_json function to parse teh values in the value column to the schema above.

paragraphs.title: 9 - Confirm the new DataFrame's schema is correct
paragraphs.text:
%md
View the new DataFrames's schema to confirm that it is correct.

paragraphs.title: 10 - Create and start a streaming query
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create and start a streaming query based on `activationsDF`. Display the output to the console using output mode `append`. The elements in the DataFrame are longer than the default output, so set the `truncate` option to `false`.

msg.data:
Create and start a streaming query based on activationsDF. Display the output
to the console using output mode append. The elements in the DataFrame are
longer than the default output, so set the truncate option to false.

paragraphs.title: 11 - Test the query output
paragraphs.text:
%md
Test the query output using the provided test script. Run the script in a separate terminal window (not running the Spark shell).

```
    /home/devuser/bin/devsh/scripts/streamtest-kafka.sh activations \
    localhost:9092 10 /user/zeppelin/activations_stream
```

This command produces Kafka messages based on the JSON lines in `/user/zeppelin/activations_stream/`. It sends the messages to the Kafka broker running on `localhost` on the `activations` topic, 10 messages per second.

When prompted, confirm that the script settings are correct.

msg.data:
Test the query output using the provided test script. Run the script in a separate
terminal window (not running the Spark shell).

$ $DEVSH/scripts/streamtest-kafka.sh activations \
localhost:9092 10 $DEVDATA/activations_stream

This command produces Kafka messages based on the JSON lines in $DEVDATA/activations_stream/.
It sends the messages to the Kafka broker running on localhost on the activations topic, 10 messages per second.

When prompted, confirm that the script settings are correct.

paragraphs.title: 12 - Run the test script for several seconds
paragraphs.text:
%md
The script will display each line from the file as it sends the corresponding Kafka message. Let the script run for several seconds, then stop it using Ctrl+C.

msg.data:
The script will display each line from the file as it sends the corresponding Kafka
message. Let the script run for several seconds, then stop it using Ctrl+C.

paragraphs.title: 13 - Review the output displayed by the streaming query
paragraphs.text:
%md
Return to the Spark shell and review the output displayed by the streaming query. Note that each element in the result DataFrame is an array of strings -- that is, the value of the `activation` column.

msg.data:
Return to the Spark shell and review the output displayed by the streaming query.
Note that each element in the result DataFrame is an array of strings – that is, the
value of the activation column.

paragraphs.title: 14 - Stopping the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
When you are done testing, stop the query by calling the `stop` function on the `StreamingQuery` object.

paragraphs.title: 15 - Optional: Perform additional transformations
paragraphs.text:
%md
*Optional:* Try performing additional transformations on the device activation data in the Kafka message stream. For instance, try counting activations by model.

msg.data:
Optional: Try performing additional transformations on the device activation data
in the Kafka message stream. For instance, try counting activations by model.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Send a Stream of Messages to a Kafka Sink

In this section, you will send Kafka messages containing information about device activations to the `activations-out` topic.

msg.data:
Send a Stream of Messages to a Kafka Sink

In this section, you will send Kafka messages containing information about device
activations to the activations-out topic.

paragraphs.title: 16 - Exit the Spark shell you started in the section above
17 - Create the topic for the output messages

msg.data:
$ kafka-topics --create --zookeeper localhost:2181 \
--partitions 2 --replication-factor 1 \
--topic activations-out

paragraphs.title: 18 - Start a Kafka consumer
paragraphs.text:
%md
Start a Kafka consumer running on the command line to test the output you will produce below.

Leave the consumer application running. You will return later to confirm your Kafka message output.

msg.data:
Start a Kafka consumer running on the command line to test the output you will produce below.

$ kafka-console-consumer --topic activations-out \
--bootstrap-server localhost:9092

Leave the consumer application running. You will return later to confirm your Kafka message output.

paragraphs.title: 19 - In a separate terminal window, restart the shell

msg.data:
$ pyspark --master local[2]

$ spark-shell --master local[2]

paragraphs.title: 20 - Create the schema for the streaming DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
The test data files for this section are the same ones you use in the previous section, containing JSON records with device activation data. You will simulate incoming streaming data by reading the existing JSON files in the data directory, one file per micro-batch trigger.

Create a schema to map the JSON values to columns.

msg.data:
The test data files for this section are the same ones you use in the previous section,
containing JSON records with device activation data. You will simulate incoming
streaming data by reading the existing JSON files in the data directory, one file per
micro-batch trigger.

a. Create a schema to map the JSON values to columns.

paragraphs.text:
%spark2
import org.apache.spark.sql.types._

val activationsSchema = StructType( List(
StructField("acct_num", IntegerType),
StructField("dev_id", StringType),
StructField("phone", StringType),
StructField("model", StringType)))

paragraphs.title: 21 - Create a simulated streaming DataFrame
paragraphs.text: Create a simulated streaming DataFrame based on the JSON activation data, using the schema you created above.

paragraphs.title: 22 - Transform the input streaming DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
Transform the input streaming DataFrame into a new DataFrame with the correct schema and content:

- A `key` column for which all rows contain an empty string ("")
    - Hint: use the Spark SQL `lit(`*literal*`)` function to specify a column with a literal value
- A `value` string column containing the account number and device ID separated by a comma.
    - Hint: use the Spark SQL `concat_ws(`*separator*`,` *columns...*`)` function create the comma-delimited string

msg.data:
Transform the input streaming DataFrame into a new DataFrame with the correct
schema and content:

  • A key column for which all rows contain an empty string (““)
    • Hint: use the Spark SQL lit(literal) function to specify a column with a
      literal value
  • A value string column containing the account number and device ID separated
    by a comma.
    • Hint: use the Spark SQL concat_ws(separator, columns…) function
      create the comma-delimited string

paragraphs.title: 23 - Create and start a query to produces Kafka messages
paragraphs.text:
%md
The query should
- Use format `kafka`
- Set the `checkpointLocation` option to `/tmp/kafka-checkpoint`
- Set the `kafka.bootstrap.servers` to `localhost:9092`
- Set the `topic` option to `activations-out`

**Note:** If you need to run the query above multiple times, be sure to remove thecheckpoint directory above before rerunning it.
```
    $ rm -rf /tmp/kafka-checkpoint
```

msg.data:
The query should

  • Use format kafka
  • Set the checkpointLocation option to /tmp/kafka-checkpoint
  • Set the kafka.bootstrap.servers to localhost:9092
  • Set the topic option to activations-out

Note: If you need to run the query above multiple times, be sure to remove the
checkpoint directory above before rerunning it.

$ rm -rf /tmp/kafka-checkpoint

paragraphs.title: 24 - Confirm that the messages are being received correctly
paragraphs.text:
%md
The query should start generating Kafka messages immediately. Return to the window where you started the console consumer to confirm that the messages are being received and have the correct format.

msg.data:
The query should start generating Kafka messages immediately. Return to the
window where you started the console consumer to confirm that the messages are
being received and have the correct format.

paragraphs.title: 25 - Stopping the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
When you are done testing, exit the consumer application using `Ctrl+C`. Then stop the query using the `stop` function and exit the Spark shell.

msg.data: When you are done testing, exit the consumer application using Ctrl+C. Then stop the query using the stop function and exit the Spark shell.

Result

You have now:
Solution

%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.

msg.data:

  1. Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
  2. Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.

  4. Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs - official Zeppelin documentation.
